summary: the pathogens causing post-viral bacterial pneumonia vary according to the type of preceding respiratory virus. mycoplasma pneumoniae was the most frequent bacterium in patients aged 16 years, regardless of the preceding virus type. the most common bacterial pathogens found in patients with post-influenza pneumonia were Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pneumoniae7,8. respiratory viral infection complicating bacterial pneumonia is associated with a worse prognosis and high mortality rate compared with respiratory viral infection only 9. the predominant bacterial species causing pneumonia secondary to respiratory viral infections other than influenza remain unknown. post-viral pneumonia was defined as the presence of pneumonia in a patient with respiratory viral infection. the results of the following tests performed within 48 hours of the hospital visit were investigated for patients with virus positivity and (radiological) pneumonia (i.e., post-viral pneumonia) statistical analysis Categorical variables are expressed as numbers and percentages. independent t test was used to evaluate statistical significance. primary study subjects were 5,298 patients who underwent multiplex real-time polymerase chain reaction. post-viral bacterial pneumonia was defined as the above (post-viral pneumonia) plus simultaneous detection of pathogenic bacteria in a respiratory specimen. results of the following tests performed within 48 hours of the hospital visit were investigated for patients with virus positivity and (radiological) pneumonia. respiratory viruses were detected in 3,328 of the 5,298 patients (62.8%) by multiplex real-time PCR. of the 3,328 patients, 704 (21.2%) were diagnosed with post-viral pneumonia according to chest radiography and/or chest CT findings. 233 of the 704 patients (33.1%) with pneumonia were identified. hMPV: human metapneumovirus;
